summary: This is a Federal Bureau of Prisons investigative report from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, detailing an incident on July 23, 2019, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with a homemade noose around his neck. The report includes interviews with Epstein and his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, medical assessments, and concludes there is insufficient evidence of an assault, recommending no separation between the inmates. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Form 583 Report of Incident and multiple staff memoranda detailing the events of July 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with a makeshift noose around his neck. The reports describe the response, Epstein's subsequent allegations against his cellmate, and the placement of Epstein on suicide watch. This document contains Bureau of Prisons records related to the July 23, 2019 incident where Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It includes staff shift logs, medical encounter reports for Epstein and his cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione, photo sheets documenting the scene, an administrative detention order, and an incident report classifying the event as self-mutilation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the report. Found in his cell with a homemade noose around his neck on July 23, 2019. Interviewed on July 31, 2019, where he claimed exhaustion and lack of sleep, denied being threatened by his cellmate, and stated he did not feel suicidal.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate at the time of the incident. Interviewed on July 31, 2019. He reported finding Epstein on the floor, thought he was having a heart attack, and stated Epstein made him uncomfortable by claiming 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states.'

persons.name: Clarke
persons.context: An officer who spoke with Epstein after the incident and relayed Epstein's allegations against Tartaglione to a lieutenant.

persons.name: Mason, D
persons.context: Appears as a staff member who approved or processed the daily assignment roster dated July 23, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Found unresponsive in his cell with a rope around his neck on July 23, 2019. Documented in medical and incident reports following the event.

persons.name: Nicholas John Tartaglione
persons.context: Was Epstein's cellmate in the Special Housing Unit at the time of the incident. Reported the event to staff and was later medically evaluated.

persons.name: MLP
persons.context: Medical provider who conducted the clinical encounter with Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019, documenting his injuries and statements.

connections.description: Were housed together in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York. The report investigates a potential incident between them but finds insufficient evidence of assault.
Officer Clarke spoke with Epstein after the incident and relayed his allegations against Tartaglione to a lieutenant.
Were housed together in cell 124 of the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York at the time of the incident.
MLP examined and documented Epstein's condition and injuries following the July 23, 2019 incident.

events.title: Epstein Found with Homemade Noose
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., staff in the Special Housing Unit observed inmate Jeffrey Epstein lying on the floor in a fetal position with a homemade noose around his neck. He was breathing heavily and responsive. He was restrained, medically examined, and placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Interview of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein was interviewed by SIS Staff. He stated he had not slept in about twenty days, was extremely tired, and only recalled getting up for water before finding himself on the floor. He denied issues with Tartaglione, despite recalling Tartaglione had called him a 'pedophile' days earlier.

events.title: Interview of Nicholas Tartaglione
events.description: Tartaglione was interviewed. He stated he was asleep on the floor when he felt something hit his foot, then observed Epstein sitting on the floor with eyes open. He called for help, thinking Epstein was having a heart attack. He recounted a disturbing conversation where Epstein said 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states.'

events.title: Epstein Placed in Administrative Detention
events.description: An Administrative Detention Order was issued, placing Jeffrey Epstein in detention pending classification.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt in MCC
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with an orange homemade rope around his neck, appearing unresponsive. Staff responded, removed the noose, and transported him to a medical unit where he was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Alleges Cellmate Attempted Murder and Extortion
events.description: After becoming responsive, Epstein told staff he believed his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been attempting to extort money from him for a week, threatening violence.

events.title: Tartaglione's Account of the Incident
events.description: Tartaglione told staff he was asleep when he felt something hit his legs, turned on the light, and saw Epstein with a string around his neck. He then called for the guards.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive in Cell
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, staff found Jeffrey Epstein unresponsive in his SHU cell with an orange homemade rope around his neck. He was breathing but unresponsive. The incident was classified as a possible suicide attempt/self-mutilation.

events.title: Epstein Medical Evaluation
events.description: At 06:20, Epstein was evaluated by MLP. He had a circular line of erythema on his neck but was ambulatory, oriented, and smiling. He stated he did not know how the injury occurred.

events.title: Tartaglione Medical Evaluation
events.description: Nicholas Tartaglione was medically evaluated in the SHU. He stated he felt good, had no complaints regarding the incident with his former cellmate, and denied any injury.

keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his prison cell with a homemade noose around his neck, resulting in visible injuries (erythema and friction marks on his neck).

Epstein's cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, reported that during a prior conversation, Epstein stated 'fourteen (14) is legal in most states and I don't understand what's the problem here,' which made Tartaglione uncomfortable.
The Bureau of Prisons investigation concluded there was 'insufficient evidence to support Epstein was assaulted by Tartaglione' and recommended no separation between the inmates.
Epstein, during his interview, denied feeling threatened by Tartaglione or feeling suicidal, attributing the incident to extreme exhaustion and lack of sleep.

The report documents that Epstein had been placed in Administrative Detention on July 10, 2019, and was subsequently written an incident report for 'code 228 - Self Mutilation' following the July 23 event.
On July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his MCC cell with a homemade orange cloth noose around his neck, appearing unresponsive.
Epstein later alleged to staff that his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, had tried to kill him and had been attempting to extort money from him, threatening violence.
Medical examination revealed a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of Epstein's neck with marks of friction, and a small erythema on his left knee.
Multiple staff memoranda provide slightly varying but consistent accounts of the initial discovery and response, including removing the noose and placing Epstein on suicide watch.
The document includes a daily staff assignment roster for July 23, 2019, showing operational staffing at the MCC.
Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York on July 23, 2019, at 1:27 AM with an orange homemade rope around his neck.
Epstein's cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, alerted staff to the incident. Epstein was breathing but unresponsive when found.
A medical exam hours later noted Epstein had a circular line of erythema on his neck but was alert, oriented, smiling, and denied pain or knowledge of how the injury occurred.
The incident was officially documented as a "Possible Suicide Attempt" and a "Self-Mutilation" prohibited act (Code 228) in a Bureau of Prisons Incident Report.
Epstein had been placed in Administrative Detention in the SHU on July 10, 2019, at his own request for protection.
